text: 2, and we'll be looking at a passage of Scripture and continuing with this series, this thought of doing what we ought to do, and we'll be looking at 1 John 2 this evening, particularly verse number 6, and we'll look at this portion of Scripture. I do believe that it will take us two to three weeks to get through this particular admonition that we find here in 1 John 2, 6, because it's such depth to the statement that is made, and I'm going to begin reading in verse number 1, 1 John chapter 2 is such a powerful, God's Word is powerful, we understand that, and all of it is powerful, it is God's Word and we're thankful to have it preserved for us, but I love 1 John chapter 2, and it begins by saying this, my little children, these things write I unto you that you sin not. If any man sin, by the way, that's all of us, right, after salvation we still sin, and of course our goal is to not sin, and that's why he says that you sin not, and as we continue to draw closer and closer to the Lord as we abide in Him and we walk with Him, we should be sinning less and less, but we'll never be sinless until we get to Heaven. And so he says if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, notice it says Jesus Christ the righteous, aren't you so thankful that we have an advocate with the Father, and it says this in verse 2, He is the propitiation for our sins, and not for ours only, but also for the sins of the whole world, and praise the Lord for that wonderful truth, I'm so thankful that Christ took my place and took your place and paid for the sin of the entire world, there's not one person that's ever walked upon the face of the earth that is beyond the ability of God's saving grace, and I'm so thankful for that. Verse 3, and hereby we do know that we know Him if we keep His commandments, he that saith I know Him and keepeth not His commandments is a liar and the truth is not in him, but whoso keepeth His word and him verily is the love of God perfected, hereby know we that we are in Him, notice verse 6, the text for our study this evening, he that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk even as He walked. I've titled the message this evening, We Ought to Walk as Christ Walked. The truth of 1 John chapter 2 and verse number 6 requires for every believer to really examine the scriptures. Why do I say that? Well, the Bible says that he that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk even as He walked. So what is it that requires some examination of the scriptures on the part of every child of God? Well, it's for us to know how Christ walked. And so we find that here as we look at this thought that we ought, that he that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk even as He walked, and then we're reminded that this truth or this thought of the phrase our walk, that throughout the Bible it is clearly understood that our walk is really referring to how we live our lives. It's not talking about our gait, in other words, how we walk physically, our posture in our particular gait in our walk. No, it's talking about our lives. It's talking about how we lead and live our lives. It's also important for us to know a concept that is found in this second chapter of First John. We find that on three occasions here in First John chapter number two, the Bible will say this, he that saith, he that saith. In our text it says he that saith he abideth in Him. Now we understand John 15, Jesus said abide in me and I in you, and He talks about the vine and the branches and the truth that's contained in that passage of Scripture, and so we understand as the people of God, the children of God, that we're to abide in Him, but here the text says he that saith he abideth in Him. Now listen, we can say whatever we want to say, but as the old saying goes, the proof is in the pudding, and here we find he that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk even as he walked. The reality is that we can ask it this way, is there evidence to support the claim? Is there evidence that supports the claim? By the way, the evidence is seen in our behavior, seen in how we live our lives, how we lead our lives.
